Vansh Shah, a 17 year old entrepreneur from India won the National Pride Award
text: Vansh Shah is a high school senior from India, and at such a young age when children are busy playing video games and get stuck in the tiny world of academics, he became an entrepreneur and found his own company. Vansh and his startup-Mirage are set to revolutionize the world using Augmented Reality. Vansh aspires to add a virtual layer of vision to the human eye using AR to partially virtualize objects, opening the doors to endless possibilities. His this idea has led him to win the National Pride Award by Sociallypoint organization and Niti Aayog of the Indian Government. We salute such inspiring personalities that keep the potential to change the world by their ideas and execution. And Vansh shows these true abilities. The entire nation congrats Vansh today.

Ask HN: Antispam rules on email source code
text:
I have a question about printing or not the antispam rules inside the cource code. I know that google doesn't print it inside the source code, I think it's done to avoid spammers to learn how avoid the antispam, etc. It's that a thing? I mean, what's the reason to put clearly the rules inside the source code of an email? When you have them inside your mail server's log I think it's enough. Am I wrong? What's your opinion about this?

Thanks!

Vansh Shah, a 17-year old building a new era of human vision with Mirage
text:
Seventeen-year-old Vansh Shah has made waves in the tech industry with his revolutionary new company, Mirage. Shah, a high school student, has created a virtual layer for human vision using augmented reality, eliminating the need for 90% of real-world substances and greatly benefiting the environment.

Mirage is the world's first web 3 decentralized experience, and introduces the world's first AR operating system, called CosmOS. This innovative system will be embedded in glasses and can be controlled by gestures and even partially by brain activity using brain-computer interfaces. CosmOS will run on a blockchain and be operated on the cloud.

Shah's company, Mirage, has the potential to completely change the way we live and interact with the world around us. With the virtualization of objects, the possibilities are endless. From virtual try-ons for clothing and makeup, to virtual furniture placement in home design, Mirage is set to revolutionize the way we use and think about technology.

As the founder of Mirage, Shah has already made a name for himself in the tech industry. His innovative ideas and dedication to creating a better future have garnered attention from top investors and industry leaders.

With the success of Mirage, Shah has proven that age is just a number and that anyone with a vision and the drive to make it a reality can truly make a difference. The world is waiting to see what other groundbreaking ideas Shah and his team at Mirage will bring to the table.

text:

Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning - Bishop

Deep Learning - Goodfellow, Bengio, Courville

Neural Smithing - Reed, Marks

Neural Networks - Haykin

Artificial Intelligence - Haugeland
